introduction.p: A charged capacitor provides a ready supply of separated charges. When you provide a conducting path for excess electrons on the negative plate to drift to positive plate, it leads to discharge of the capacitor. This process releases electrical energy in a short time.

p.p: To use charges on a charged capacitor one can connect the ends of the capacitor through a device of resistance R and a switch S as indicated in . When the switch is closed, current flows in the circuit until electrons from the negative plate neutralize the positive charges on the positive plate.

introduction.p:
Rate of discharge depends on the current value of charges on the plates, which leads to charge decaying exponentially. Let Q_0 be the starting charge at t=0. Then, using Calculus, it will be shown below that charge remaining on capacitor at time t will be
Q(t) = Q_0 e^{ - t/RC}.
A plot of this function versus time is shown in . The rate of discharge, i.e., current in the circuit varies with time and is proportional to the charge on the plates at the instant.
\text{Rate of discharge } = \dfrac{1}{RC}\, Q(t).

The time to reach \dfrac{1}{e} of the original charge, where e is the Euler number with value e = 2.718..., is an important characteristic of the circuit. This time is called time constant of the circuit. The time constant is usually denoted by the Greek letter \tau. Of course, during this time, 1-1/e of the charge, which is approximately two-thirds of the charge, has been discharged through the circuit. The time constant of the circuit in is product of the resistance and capacitance of the circuit.
\tau = RC.
By adjusting R we can congtrol the rate at which dischsrging of a capacitor can take place. In another section, we will study charging process. We will find there that the rate of charging has also the same time constant.

subsection.title: (Calculus) Equation of Motion for Discharging a Capacitor
subsection.p:
Let us examine discharging circuit in at instant t. Let I(t) be current in the circuit, \pm Q(t) be charges on the plates. The potential drop V_c across the capacitor is given by the capacitor equation.
V_c(t) = \dfrac{Q(t)}{C}.

sidebyside.p:
By Kirchhoff's Loop Rule on the loop a-b-a' in , we find the following equation for relation among these quantities.
-R I + V_c = 0.
Current I is rate at which charge is decreasing in time. Therefore,
I = - \dfrac{dQ}{dt}.

subsection.p:
From Eqs. to gives the following equations for rate at which charge drops in time.
\dfrac{dQ}{dt} = - \dfrac{1}{RC}\, Q.
Let \pm Q_0 be the charges on capcitor plates at t=0, when the circuit switch was closed. Then, Eq. can be solved to show that charge at an arbitrary instant t \gt 0 will be
Q(t) = Q_0\, e^{- t / RC}.
A plot of Q versus t presented in shows the exponential decaying behavior of the discharge process.

figure.caption: Charge on positive plate decays exponentially with time with a time constant \tau= RC. The time constant is equal to the time for charge to decay to 1/e of its initial value.

subsection.p:
Plots of current I vs t and potential drop across the capacitor V_c vs t show similar plots.
I \amp = -\dfrac{dQ}{dt} = \dfrac{Q_0}{RC}\, e^{- t / RC}. V_c \amp = \dfrac{Q}{C} = \dfrac{Q_0}{C}\, e^{- t / RC}.

exercise.title: Numerical Example of Discharging a Capacitor

statement.p: Consider a capacitor of capacitance 2\;\mu\text{F}. (a) Find the time constant of a circuit when the capacitor is connected to a 1.0\text{ k}\Omega resistor. (b) Suppose the capacitor was charged to contain 5.0\;\mu\text{C} at t = 0. At what time will there be 2.0\;\mu\text{C} left on the capacitor?

hint.p: Use the solution of discharging circuit.

solution.title: (a)
solution.p:
(a) The time constant follows from the result \tau = RC for this circuit given above.
\tau = RC = 1000\ \Omega\times 2\times 10^{-6}\text{ F} = 2\times 10^{-3}\text{ sec} = 2\text{ ms}.

solution.title: (b)
solution.p:
(b) Using , we set up the following equation for charge at an unknown time.
2\ \mu\text{C} = 5\ \mu\text{C} \times \exp{\left(-\frac{t}{2\text{ ms} } \right)}
Therefore, we have the following exponential equation to solve.
\exp{\left(-\frac{t}{2 \text{ms} } \right)} = 0.4.
Taking natural logarithm of both sides converts this equation into a linear equation for the unknown t.
-\frac{t}{2 \text{ ms} } = \ln(0.4),
which gives t=1.8\text{ ms}.
